Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Advanced Nanoindentation System for Multidisciplinary Research and Training

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art nanoindentation system to catalyze fundamental research leading to more resilient infrastructure, novel materials, advances in medical treatment and energy production, and enhanced vehicle and aircraft design. Nanoindentation is an important tool for measuring mechanics at a small scale; this instrumentation has nanomechanical characterization capabilities that are not available at the University of Washington (UW) or the Pacific Northwest. It will enable multidisciplinary research, education and outreach at the UW and partner schools. More than 10 research associates and 50 graduate researchers will be trained on the instrument annually, greatly expanding the next generation of researchers with nanomechanical characterization experience. The system will facilitate educational programs at four regional partner institutions and public outreach events in the annual "Meet the Mammals" family day at the Burke Museum and "Engineering Discovery Days" of the UW College of Engineering. These activities enhance public understanding and help to attract the next generation to careers in science, technology, engineering and math.

The Hysitron TI 980 Triboindenter, with an ultra-low noise floor down to 1 nN force and 0.01 nm displacement, is equipped with a powerful multi-head base capable of seamlessly operating multiple measurement modes such as nanoindentation, nanoscratch, and nanowear. Complemented with high temperature, high/low load, conductive and submerged indentation options, the system will enable researchers to pursue advanced knowledge from the nano and molecular levels in energy and health, to the micro and larger scales in aerospace and infrastructure renewal. It will enable engineers to study biological, cementitious and granulated materials, composites, metals and polymers, and medical, health science and dental researchers to investigate the biomechanics of cells, tissues to whole organs. It will facilitate fundamental understanding in pulsed-laser strengthening of metallic multi-layers, the properties of nanohelical ferromagnetic robotic actuators, and the mechanical performance of semiconducting organic polymers, high temperature composites, and polymer composite sensors. The instrument will also enable studies aimed at extending the durability of next-generation li-ion battery electrode materials. Lastly, new research will be possible regarding strategies for age-related degradation of hard tissues, for improving adhesive bonds to hard tissues, and for remineralizing hard tissues assisted by amelogenin-derived peptides. The system will become a major regional resource to researchers at the University of Washington and the greater Pacific Northwest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoindentation is a powerful technique for characterizing the mechanical behavior of materials where either the size or structural hierarchy precludes the use of conventional macro-scale technique. The University of Washington (UW) has a core group of faculty with primary research interests in the area of mechanical behavior of materials, which range from biological cells, tissues and biomaterials to engineering nano and micromaterials such as metals, polymers, and composites. Applications span the fields of aerospace, energy, health and medicine. In this project, a state-of-the-art nanoindentation system was acquired to expand the research activities, cultivate greater cross-department and cross-institution collaborations, and strengthen the educational and research opportunities at the UW and the greater Pacific Northwest region. The acquired system, a Bruker Hysitron Ti 980 is equipped with not only standard nanoindentation, nanoscratch, and nanowear, but with many advanced options such as nanoDMA, ultrafast property mapping, high and low temperature, high and low load, conductive and submerged indentation which provided the researchers unprecedented opportunities to pursue advanced knowledge from the nano and molecular levels in energy and health, to the micro and larger scales in aerospace and infrastructure renewal.

 

Thus far this project has provided training to a total of 48 users (30 male, 18 female; 1 faculty member, 2 postdoc, 4 undergraduates, 37 graduates, and 4 industrial researchers) to conduct independent research. An additional 120 undergraduate and graduate students have been exposed to the technique through classroom lectures and lab demonstrations in courses such as ME461/561 Mechanics of Thin Films, and MSE 462 Mechanical Behaviors of Materials. Research activities have been conducted on a wide range of topics including: 1) strengthening mechanisms of metallic multilayer thin films, 2) mechanical and microstructural property correlation of biological materials such as fish scale and isopod exoskeletons, 3) powder reuse in electron beam melting metal additive manufacturing, 4) non-fouling and lubricious surface coatings for orthopedic implants, 5) micromechanics of microscale tensegrity structures, 6) electromechanical measurement of piezoelectric thin films, 7) age-related root fracture in human enamel, etc. Findings from these projects are facilitating improved understanding toward the development of high performance metallic multilayer thin films for sliding contact applications, design of light weight and tough body armors, improved reusability and lifetime of powder feedstock in metal 3D printing, the root cause of enamel fracture in seniors, and better antifouling coating for orthopedic implants. A number of manuscripts are in the process of being submitted, under review or published. As soon as the COVID-crisis is over and training of new users (which has been suspended since March 2020) is resumed, greatly increased activities including the number of projects, users and productivities will be anticipated.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2020
Modified by: Junlan Wang
